Raymie writes:
> Mercator didn't parse forms.  Have our QA efforts
> indicated that this would yield better collections?  Seems to me
> that we should consider this only after such an empirical indication.

There are just a couple of anecdotal instances from test crawls
of content that (might have) been missed without form-following.

One example is the drop-down selector atop:

http://www.fco.gov.uk/servlet/Front?pagename=OpenMarket/Xcelerate/ShowPage&c=Page&cid=1007029390590

It just so happens that we get all the per-country pages, because
they're linked elsewhere, but we could easily miss such material
on other sites.

(Because of a Wayback Machine limitation, this was reported by
an outside QA effort.)

Another is the common practice of putting valid, often
relative URI-paths inside <INPUT> or <OPTION> VALUE 
attributes. 

Apparently at least one of our test crawlers were getting 
these (HTTrack?), so we're now applying to these values
the same "is this plausibly a url/path?" test as is used on 
Javascript strings.

- Gordon
